Criminal Law;no;What is the principle of legality according to Section 1 of the Hungarian Criminal Code?;"The principle of legality according to Section 1 of the Hungarian Criminal Code is that the criminal liability of the perpetrator shall be established only for an act which was punishable under an Act at the time of commission
column2: except for acts punishable under the generally recognised rules of international law [1].

column1: Criminal Law;yes;Explain the difference between intentional and negligent commission of a criminal offence. How does the 'liability for result' affect qualifying circumstances?;"The difference between intentional and negligent commission of a criminal offence lies in the level of awareness and intent behind the act.
Intentional commission of a criminal offence refers to acts committed with the intention of causing harm or violating the law
column2: as stated in Section 3(1) of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code [1]. On the other hand
column3: negligent commission of a criminal offence refers to acts committed without the intention of causing harm
column4: but still resulting in a violation of the law
column5: as stated in Article XXVIII(4) of the Fundamental law [2].

column1: The 'liability for result' affects qualifying circumstances in the following ways: Liability for result as a qualifying circumstance is governed by Section 9 of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code [1]. According to this provision
column2: the more severe legal consequences attached to the result of a criminal offence shall only be applied if the perpetrator was at least negligent regarding the result.

column1: Additionally
column2: liability for hazardous operations is governed by Section 6:535 of the Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code [2]
column3: which states that a person carrying out hazardous activities shall compensate for the resulting damage
column4: unless they can prove that the damage was caused by an unavoidable event outside the scope of the hazardous activity.

column1: Furthermore
column2: liability in damages in the event of gratuitous contracts is addressed in Section 6:147 of the Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code [3]
column3: which states that the person undertaking the performance of a service free of charge shall be liable for the damage incurred in the subject of the service if the obligee proves that the obligor caused the damage by an intentional breach of contract
column4: or failed to provide information on a substantial characteristic of the service which was unknown to the obligee.

column1: Finally
column2: when establishing responsibility and/or the amount of damages
column3: all circumstances of the case shall be taken into consideration
column4: including those affecting the employee's liability and which may have influenced the safe and proper administration of inventories
column5: as stated in Section 187 of the Act I of 2012 on the Labor Code [4].

Civil Law;no;According to the Civil Code, when does a person reach majority and what happens if a marriage is declared invalid?;A person reaches majority at the age of 18 according to the Fundamental Law [1]. However

column1: Regarding the declaration of invalid marriage
column2: the Hungarian Civil Code provides rules for this situation. According to Section 4:14 [1]
column3: a marriage may be considered as invalid if its invalidity is established by the court in an action brought for this end. A judgment establishing the invalidity of a marriage shall be effective against all [2]. An invalid marriage shall attract the legal consequences set out in this Act [3].

column1: If the marriage is annulled
column2: property claims may be enforced by either spouse as if the marriage had been dissolved by the court at the time of the establishment of its invalidity [4]. If its invalidity was established after the death of one of the spouses
column3: property claims may be enforced as if the marriage had terminated upon the death of that spouse [4].

column1: An action for annulment may be brought either during the marriage or after the termination of the marriage [5]. Unless otherwise provided in this Act
column2: an action for annulment may be brought by either spouse
column3: the prosecutor or any person with a legal interest in the establishment of the invalidity of the marriage [5].

column1: If both spouses acted in good faith upon the conclusion of an invalid marriage
column2: the property consequences of the marriage shall be identical to the property effect of a valid marriage [6].

column2: starting on the day when the spouse regains his capacity to act
column3: on the ground of having no capacity to act at the time of the conclusion of marriage [7].

column1: Civil Law;yes;Distinguish between legal capacity and capacity to act under the Civil Code. What specific juridical acts can a minor with limited capacity to act perform without their statutory representative?;"The legal capacity and capacity to act are two distinct concepts under the Civil Code. Legal capacity refers to the ability of a person to enter into legal relationships and perform legal acts
column2: as defined in the Civil Code [1]. This includes the capacity to conclude contracts
column4: and perform other legal acts. Capacity to act
column6: refers to the ability of a person to perform a specific legal act
column7: such as concluding a contract or making a will [2]. This capacity may be affected by factors such as age
column9: or other circumstances that may impact a person's ability to perform a particular legal act.

column1: In summary
column2: legal capacity is a broader concept that encompasses the ability to enter into legal relationships and perform legal acts
column3: while capacity to act is a more specific concept that refers to the ability to perform a particular legal act.

column1: A minor with limited capacity to act can perform certain juridical acts without their statutory representative. According to Section 2:15
column2: when making juridical acts that affect the minor himself or his property
column3: statutory representatives shall take the views of the minor having no capacity to act but of sound mind into account in accordance with the age and maturity of the minor [3]. Additionally
column4: minors having limited capacity to act and persons having partially limited capacity to act in terms of juridical acts concerning the establishment of parentage may bring an action subject to the consent of their statutory representative [4].

column1: Sources:
[1] Fundamental law
[2] Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code
[3] Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code
[4] Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code

column5: misinterpreting the cited Civil Code sections which either require representative action or consent.

column1: Criminal Law;yes;In which specific cases does Hungarian criminal law apply to acts committed abroad by persons who are not Hungarian nationals?;"Hungarian criminal law applies to acts committed abroad by persons who are not Hungarian nationals in the following specific cases:

Hungarian criminal law applies to acts committed by persons other than Hungarian nationals abroad if the act constitutes a criminal offence under Hungarian law and is also punishable under the law of the place where it was committed [1]. Additionally
column2: Hungarian criminal law applies to acts committed by persons other than Hungarian nationals abroad against a Hungarian national
column3: or a legal person or other legal entity without legal personality established under Hungarian law
column4: which are punishable under the Hungarian law [2]. Furthermore
column5: Hungarian criminal law applies to acts committed by Hungarian nationals abroad if the act constitutes a criminal offence under Hungarian law [3].
